title: Link relation
text:
A link relation is a descriptive attribute attached to a <a href="hyperlink">hyperlink</a> in order to define the type of the link, or the relationship between the source and destination resources. The attribute can be used by automated systems, or can be presented to a user in a different way.
In <a href="HTML">HTML</a> these are designated with the attribute on , , or elements. Example uses include the standard way of referencing <a href="Cascading%20Style%20Sheets">CSS</a>, , which indicates that the external resource linked to with the attribute is a stylesheet, so a <a href="web%20browser">web browser</a> will generally fetch this file to render the page. Another example is for the popular <a href="favicon">favicon</a> icon.
Link relations are used in some <a href="microformat">microformat</a>s (e.g. for <a href="Tag%20%28metadata%29">tagging</a>), in <a href="XHTML%20Friends%20Network">XHTML Friends Network</a> (XFN), and in the <a href="Atom%20%28standard%29">Atom standard</a>, in <a href="XLink">XLink</a>, as well as in HTML. Standardized link relations are one of the foundations of <a href="HATEOAS">HATEOAS</a> as they allow the user agent to understand the meaning of the available state transitions in a <a href="Representational%20State%20Transfer">REST</a> system.
The <a href="Internet%20Engineering%20Task%20Force">Internet Engineering Task Force</a> (IETF) has a registry of standardized link relations, and a procedure for extending it defined in RFC 5988. <a href="HTML5">HTML5</a> also defines valid link relations.
In HTML4, the rev attribute of a link is also defined, which defines the reversed relationship between the resources. The attribute is removed in <a href="HTML5">HTML5</a>.
Semantic Web implementation.
The <a href="Resource%20Description%20Framework">RDF</a> typed links are fundamental in <a href="Linked%20data%23Datasets">LOD datasets</a> for identifying the relationship (predicate) type of RDF triples, contributing to the automatic processability of machine-readable statements of the <a href="Giant%20Global%20Graph">Giant Global Graph</a> on the <a href="Semantic%20Web">Semantic Web</a>. The typed links in RDF are expressed as the value of the codice_1 property, defining the relationship type using well-established <a href="controlled%20vocabulary">controlled vocabulary</a> terms or definitions from LOD datasets such as
<rdf:type rdf:resource="http://schema.org/Person" />
